author: muesliswap
title: Sharing liquidity between DEXs
description:
On Cardano each DEX uses its own "orderbook". Downsides

The need for aggregation tools to find optimal prices
Limit orders can only be placed against one protocol at a time
DEX specific, low liquidity

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal meets the challenge setting. It will increase the availability of tooling on Cardano, the liquidity accessed by all DEXs, and will provide users a very convenient approach to swaps. Currently, if a user wants to swap a particular token, they have to first find a DEX that has a liquidity token pair of that particular token. With this model, a user can go to one place for their swaps. Additionally, new DEXs or startups can provide their users access to greater liquidity without having to bootstrap the liquidity. Most importantly, the proposer offers this solution as an open source project, which means they will be providing a valuable and audited code base for batching, should a project wish to host their own DEX. This is a good example of a project that is showing how Cardano is different and better, in this particular case, than the competitors. Projects like this will bring greater adoption from other ecosystems. Muesli Swap team is a highly competent and trustworthy group, and I have no doubt they will follow through on their promise.
f6_assessments.q1: I have been a member of the community for over a year now, and from personal experience, I can say that the Muesli Swap team has already proven to the community that they offer value, and can be depended on to bring a product to market. They have been very open and honest with the community and are well respected. The proposal as written is highly likely of being implemented, baring any unforeseen challenges. I am not aware of any other protocols in crypto that offer this type of service. The proposers are asking for a modest amount of Ada and has made it clear they intend to use internal funding as well to get the project across the finish line. In addition, the team is well-connected in the community, and they will not have any issues getting other DEXs on board.
f6_assessments.q2: The Muesli Swap team has already proven that they do communicate with the community and are open about their intentions. The proposer in this case is going to offer communications through Twitter Spaces, an open GitHub repository so that the community can view the code base, will write a technical paper outlining the protocol, and will have it professionally audited and provide that audit to the community. As the proposer mentions, this project will be implemented regardless of funding, and will be introduced into major DEXs.

f6_assessments.q0: In essence instead of quoting orders in every other Dex's orderbook separately trying to find the best possible rates of entry with minimal slippage,we instead have created an shared orderbook wherein one would get the orders filled and routed to be filled at most efficient pricepoints across various pools by the Dex's that get integrated and agree to do so .The team calls it the Meta-Dex protocol.Once an order is placed the Dex's would be able to quote the best possible price to fulfill them.The upsides are one can place limit orders across multiple dex's at the same time and optimal price quotes from various dex's with the best possible liquidity pools.This would massively improve the user experience for a new comer with little to no knowledge about liquidity pool depths and ensures much efficient execution by routing orders acrosss multiple Dex's.This is also extremely unique to the Cardano's eutxo model.
f6_assessments.q1: Although the proposal could be implemented this requires for multiple Cardano Dex's to agree upon to use this shared orderbook model which would be quite challenging considering the smartcontract risks and the fact that they wouldn't want to lose their exisisting users who are much likely to ignore the price quoting points while executing a trade thus getting into the problem of losing trading fees for their respective liquidity providers thereby making them migrate their liquidities to pools that are efficient and have bigger liquidity.Which brings to the question of should the team have most likely discussed these and try to onboard as many Dex's as possible before working on the research and implementation phase if they are confident enough on the architechture that's involved to strenghthen the quality of this proposal.The team has been trying to build the best possible infrastructure and have been constantly upto the tasks by also bringining in unique innovations like here which are extremely appreciateble.However the initial rollout would most likely involve dex's with lesser liquidities as quoted from the teams itself considering the competitiveness involved.
f6_assessments.q2: The team initially would publish their technical findings report anyalysing the advantages and disadvantages and ooen sourcing their github repositories.The team has been highly approachable with their communications regarding their findings through twitter spaces and a discord server to ask questions to the development team.The success of this implementation would mean for various dex's to use their orderbook being created for a much improved user experience.The development costs and timelines mentioned are well detailed and sufficient information on tracking these are evident.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a fascinating proposal that will enrich the Cardano ecosystem once implemented. The team is proposing to build an open order book that can be used by any DEX to fill orders. This in turn will allows users to place limit orders and use the liquidity of all participating DEXs. As a consequence, traders will get better price outcomes and liquidity will be significantly increased. It is a novel application built on top of Cardano that will enhance the ecosystem through innovation and likely boost more adoption. The goals of the proposal align with the challenge settings since a successful implementation would mean a new product available on the Cardano blockchain that will attract new users and an increased number of integrations that bring existing solutions together for a more seamless experience. Furthermore, I believe it would be enlightening to see a discussion on possible scalability issues that could arise when developing the solution.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal was made by the OpenSwap Technologies team, composed of 9 developers with experience in Haskell, Plutus and JavaScript, among others. In their website you can find short descriptions for 7 members of the team but no links to LinkedIn pages or more detailed curriculums. In the budget breakdown they estimate the number of hours of work that will be required to implement the plan but they don't get to identify how many and which type of members will be necessary. On the other hand, the budget is clearly outlined and it is easy to spot how much each item will cost. However, I found the estimates a bit overpriced. The average hourly cost of development is roughly USD 90 and the audit cost is USD 15k (and they say this amount actually won't be enough to cover all the audit costs). The timetable, in turn, sounds achievable and realistic. In total, the project is estimated to last roughly four months (the audit phase is the hardest to predict and could stretch the project). Finally, they appropriately discussed the risks of the proposal and identified the risk of other dApp protocols not being interested in using this approach. However, to mitigate that they will use this approach in MueliSwap so smaller DEXs can fulfill their order with their smart contracts. They also plan on operating their own bots to be able to fulfill the orders with liquidity from other DEXs meaning that they will be able to offer the shared limit order approach anyway.
f6_assessments.q2: The roadmap provided is a bit too simplistic. They estimate the development phase will last from two to three months, the protocol corporations will happen in parallel to that and the audit phase will last around one month. However, they could have better explained what they are expecting to happen during these three months of development. In the budget breakdown section, we can get a gist of that but it would be better if that was also on the detailed plan and if each smaller task inside the development had an estimated beginning date and an estimated finishing date. Another downside of the plan is they do not have explicitly defined KPIs to track the project's progress. Some suggestions of KPIs would be number of DEXs onboarded into the protocol, total volume traded through the protocol and total number of new users in each of the DEXs participating in the protocol. Finally, they mention their intention of updating the Cardano community weekly via twitter but it would have been more convenient if they had provided the link to their twitter account.

f6_assessments.q0:
The prospect of a shared order book between DEXes is an intriguing one, and could potentially address the three problems listed. Further, creating a shared order book is an opportunity to leverage Cardano's particular infrastructure and further distinguish it from its competitors. 

Much of the impact, unfortunately, revolves around issues not entirely within the project's control such as whether individual DEXes will want to, or fear to, cede some of their control to a "centralized" order book. Nevertheless, the order book doesn't need to corner the market to provide a good case study for the pros and cons of such a system.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal is from the team that built MuesliSwap, so they have substantial experience developing infrastructure for DEXes on Cardano. The budget is more than reasonable for the task, with the team making up for any shortfall. 

The main question, as noted in the proposal's risk assessment, is whether DEXes will shy away from using a centralized order book. MuesliSwap's commitment to using it themselves should help build some confidence. Forming relationships, particularly with smaller existing and upcoming DEXes, will be key to this project's ultimate success.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal makes transparency a high-priority, not just for the completed project, but during development itself. Development will be open source with code available to examine on repositories. 

Ultimately, it will probably take time to see what kind of effect a common order book has on the DEX-based ecosystem within Cardano. The proposers, however, plan to hire external auditers to evaluate the effects of the product, which should hold the project to account quite well.

f6_assessments.q0:
MuesliSwap returns to Fund 9 with a very interesting value proposition - the creation of an open order book that can be used by any Cardano-based DEX to fill its orders. This solution will act as a meta-dex protocol as the team calls it, or as a mem-pool of orders, a pond in which all DEXes can fish. If such a meta-protocol is built and even if a few, not all, DEXes adopt it, this can only mean a better order execution for users, which can potentially increase liquidity and decrease execution time. 

There is no real downside to this, except perhaps the open question of whether the meta protocol can be used by an automated market maker like SundaeSwap as well (a type of DEX that does not use an order book, but rather liquidity pools). Irrespective of the answer to this question, there are only upsides to building such a protocol and definitely a scalable solution if it will be used by multiple exchanges. Five stars.
f6_assessments.q1:
MuesliSwap is an already recognized name in the Cardano ecosystem, and they already have a significant number of developers on their team as well as their own financial resources, so there are minimal risks that this project will not be completed. 

The budget they are asking for would cover 400+ hours of work and an external audit, and any cost overruns would be covered by MuesliSwap. The takeaway here is that this proposal would only cover partially the project’s needs - which is excellent. 

There is a clear value proposition here, an established and well regarded team, so no need to beat around the bush. A highly feasible and potentially useful project. Five stars.
f6_assessments.q2: The team is trying to be very transparent. Once they finalize the technical proposal they plan on releasing a report with the proposed model and a discussion around advantages / disadvantages of each finding. They plan on having weekly updates released through their Twitter page. Of course, the build would be open source and available in a Github repository. Another excellent point is that the team is consulting with external parties before selecting a third party auditor - a very modest approach compared to other proposals who are not offering indications of shopping around for the best deals when selecting an auditor. I have all reasons to believe that this will be a highly transparent project and very easy to monitor by the community. Five stars.

f6_assessments.q0: The problem presented by the MuesliSwap Team is there's still not a fully decentralized exchange orderbook being shared by the current DEX(s) on the Cardano blockchain. The solution to this problem is creating an open sourced code for an orderbook via smart contracts which can be used and shared by any decentralized exchange on Cardano, yielding the best possible price for users while liquidity is shared with all DEX protocols. This would unify the market/limit orders lowering the risk among all the DEX's users and prevent any uncertainty of price throughout the market. The Impact that this could have, if the major DEX(s) on Cardano agree to implementation, is quite significant if successfully launched. The team wants to take advantage of the blockchain's EUTXO model and improve the competitive Cardano DApp ecosystem with said proposal. The rationale for this proposal is a 5 based on the positive Impact it could have on the entire Cardano ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer states there will be a total of nine members on the development team and possible use of external sources for the auditing process needed to carry out this proposal successfully. The MuesliSwap team has already showed they're more than capable and experienced with the Cardano blockchain technology, including Plutus smart contracts, which will be much needed in the creation of said protocol for the DEX orderbook open source code. The actual members profile's cannot be found easily via the links provided, making it difficult to identify and fact check their credentials. The Github link here:(https://github.com/MuesliSwapTeam) shows more on what's being worked on behind the scenes providing some transparency, along with the MuesliSwap's twitter account. There is a feasible plan in place to account for the development time & cost (roughly $50,000) to fulfill such tasks over a course of 4 months; estimating the audit process could take longer if revisions later on must be made. The overall Feasibility of the proposal is a 5 based on the amount requested for such a large experienced team and any further costs that arise will be covered by MuesliSwap.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer provided sufficient information regarding the planned roadmap and it's milestones given within a reasonable timeline. Over the course of 4 months after funding, the development team will be updating the community during Twitter Spaces (public QA's) and further detailed progress reports using the Github link shared above for public transparency. The proposer understands the clear considerable risks and challenges but does not foresee them being detrimental to the proposal's success, other than the auditing of the protocol itself which could pose minor delays before launching of the project. It is reiterated by the proposer that even if Community outreach to other Cardano Dex(s) are not made, Muesliswap will implement the project's protocol in order to hopefully enhance the entire DeFi ecosystem of Cardano and allow even more decentralization on chain. The key metrics for success will be dependent on the adoption of the open sourced protocol throughout the dApps and DEX(s) on Cardano. The rationale for Auditability is a 4 based on the understanding that not everyone from Project Catalyst and other members will tune into Twitter Spaces for updates.

f6_assessments.q0:
This project aims to develop open-source, high-quality code that can benefit the Cardano Dapp ecosystem's unique eUTXO model. 

 In other words, it advances the opensource code base by providing a common orderbook from which all DEX orders could potentially be fulfilled. This yields the best possible price outcome for users, regardless of platform.  Moreso, on a philosophical level, it creates a truly decentralized liquidity pool for the blockchain DEXs.

Lastly, a secondary benefit is that new it provides a batching script for new projects, which will be "heavily audited and battle-tested."
f6_assessments.q1:
The plan is entirely feasible, based on existing scripts/technology and the reputational success of the MuesliSwap development team (OpenSwap Technologies).  Muesliswap was the first major DAapp, launching in November 2021, and continues to operate multiple smart contracts on the mainnet.  

Two important notes made in the proposal are (1) the team will cover any overage costs beyond the requested funds, and (2) regardless of additional Dapp engagement, the smart contract and bots will be created and in place for future use, particularly for smaller/newer DEXs or Dapps to come.
f6_assessments.q2:
The team is going to great lengths to be as transparent as possible, including:
 planned weekly updates via their twitter space; opensource repositories on GitHub for public viewing; a 3rd party audit, whose cost is included in the budget of the funding proposal.

solution: We want to develop an open order book that can be used by any DEX to fill orders. This meta-dex protocol allows users to place limit orders and use the liquidity of all participating DEXs.
experience: We are OpenSwap Technologies - the team behind MuesliSwap, one of the biggest decentralized apps on Cardano. As developers of DeFi infrastructure, we have experience with all relevant aspects of Cardano (off-chain, on-chain code), haskell programming and smart contract audits.
